Graphical abstract A family of iridium(III) complexes with a general structure, [Ir(C^N)2(N^N)]PF6 (C^N is cyclometalating ligand and N^N is bipyridyl ligand), was synthesized and explored as photosensitizers (PSs) for photocatalytic hydrogen generation using a three-component system containing an electron donor, triethylamine (TEA), a colloidal platinum catalyst and water. The introduction of a novel fluorinated C^N ligand, 2-(2,4-difluorophenyl)-4-methylquinoline, leads to much faster electron transfer from TEA to the excited-state Ir-PSs, as confirmed from Stern–Volmer measurements. In combination with the employment of various N^N ligands attached with surface-adsorbing groups including vinyl, formyl, cyano, and pyridyl, the photocatalytic hydrogen-generation duration is significantly extended. This might be related to the fast quenching of the reduced state (Ir-PS−) resulting from the enhanced interaction between the Ir-PSs and the Pt catalyst. In photocatalytic reactions at relatively low Ir-PS concentrations, turnover numbers of over 10,000 for hydrogen generation can be attained using the formyl Ir-PS. Keywords Hydrogen Iridium Photosensitizer Formyl group Photochemistry 1 Introduction Hydrogen is an extremely environment friendly fuel as when it burns it releases only water vapor into the atmosphere, and thus has a great deal of applications such as in fuel cells and batteries [1–7]. Various strategies have been explored to generate hydrogen cleanly and efficiently [8–12]. Conversion of solar energy into chemical energy through light-driven water splitting can generate environmentally benign oxygen and hydrogen, providing a carbon-free fuel with the highest energy output relative to molecular weight [13,14]. The major task in this field is to develop robust and highly efficient photocatalytic materials. So far, two important categories of materials, inorganic semiconductor nanocrystals and transition metal complexes, have been intensively investigated as either photosensitizers (PSs) or photocatalysts for photocatalytic hydrogen generation [13,14]. The metal complexes generally consist of a transition metal center and surrounding inorganic or organic ligands. This specific structure can normally form unique metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) transitions, giving long triplet excited-state lifetimes, which is critical to the charge separation and transfer process [15,16]. Furthermore, the versatile choices of metal ions and ligands allow the photonic and electronic properties to be tuned at molecular levels. A number of metal complexes with Ru(II) [17], Zn(II) [18–20], Pt(II) [21], Re(I) [22] or Ir(III) [23–32] centers were reported to be active PSs for hydrogen generation. The Ir(III) complexes with a heteroleptic structure, [Ir(C^N)2(N^N)]PF6 (C^N is cyclometalating ligand and N^N is bipyridyl ligand), have been attracting intensive attention since the first report by Bernhard et al. [23] due to their ordered electronic structure. Specifically, the highest occupied molecular orbitals (HOMOs) are located predominately on the Ir(III) metal center and two C^N ligands, while the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) are mainly located on the N^N ligand [29]. This means that the HOMO and LUMO in an Ir-PS molecule are spatially separated. In a three-component hydrogen-generation reaction containing an Ir-PS, an electron donor (e.g., triethylamine (TEA)), and a catalyst (e.g., colloidal platinum) (Fig. 1 ), the photoreaction follows a reductive-quenching pathway with the light excitation (Ir-PS+hv →Ir-PS∗), the quenching of the excited state by TEA (Ir-PS∗ +TEA→Ir-PS− +TEA+), and the quenching of the reduced state by Pt catalyst [Ir-PS− +Pt(H+)→Ir-PS+Pt+1/2H2] [29]. In this regard, the quenching of Ir-PS∗ by TEA is greatly influenced by the HOMO-locating C^N ligands, while the quenching of Ir-PS− by catalyst is mainly determined by the LUMO-locating N^N ligand. The effect of the C^N ligands on the quenching of Ir-PS∗ by TEA was investigated by Lo et al. [30] through Stern–Volmer measurements. The results showed that the widely used phenylpyridine Ir-PS (PS7, Fig. 2 ) presented much faster quenching rate of the excited state by TEA than a phenylquinoline Ir-PS (PS6, Fig. 2), despite the better light absorption of the latter [30]. The effect of the N^N ligand has also been examined [26,27,31,32], showing that the introduction of surface-adsorbing groups, such as vinyl (CHCH2) [26,32], formyl (CHO) [31], and pyridyl (C6H4N) [27], to the bipyridyl ligand resulted in improved interactions between Pt catalyst and Ir-PSs, and thus fast quenching of the Ir-PS−. In the Ir-PS− state, an electron populates on the antibonding orbital, which induces the N^N ligand to dissociate readily from the Ir metal center [29]. The fast quenching of Ir-PS− by the improved Pt/Ir-PS interactions is thus a way to increase the stability of the Ir-PS molecules, and accordingly the duration of the hydrogen-generation reactions. For a highly efficient PS, it is critical to simultaneously meet the requirements of broad light absorption and fast electron transfers from the electron donor to the PS and from the PS to the catalyst. This is certainly a challenge in the molecular manipulation. In this study, a successful example of Ir-PS is exhibited in the fulfillment of the above three key aspects. First, phenylquinoline was used as the C^N ligand parent structure for stronger light absorption of its Ir-PSs than the phenylpyridine counterpart [30]. Secondly, fluorination on the phenylquinoline ligand was adopted to alter the electrochemical properties for fast quenching of Ir-PS∗ by TEA. Thirdly, various N^N ligands attached with different surface-adsorbing groups including vinyl (CHCH2), formyl (CHO), cyano (CN), and pyridyl (C6H4N) were employed to enhance the quenching rate of Ir-PS− by the Pt catalyst [26,27,31,32]. With these strategies, a family of new Ir-PSs (Fig. 2) were synthesized and examined as PSs for photocatalytic hydrogen generation. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis All chemical reagents were used as received unless otherwise noted. Anhydrous dichloromethane was obtained from distillation over CaH2. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded on 400MHz spectrometer, and chemical shifts (δ) are reported in ppm and coupling constants (J) in Hz. N^N ligand L1 was purchased from Aldrich, while L2 [32], L3 [31], and L4 [33] were synthesized following the reported procedures. Found: C, 53.3; H, 3.6; N, 6.4. 2.2 PS characterizations UV–Vis absorption spectra were recorded on a Cary 500 UV–Vis spectrophotometer. Steady-state photoluminescence (PL) was recorded on a SENS-9000 spectrophotometer. Time-resolved PL was carried out using QM4 with time-correlated single-photon-counting (TCSPC) capability. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and differential pulse voltammetry (DPV) measurements were performed using BASi Epsilon-EC workstation with anhydrous dichloromethane solvent, glass carbon working electrode, platinum wire counter electrode, Ag/AgNO3 (0.1M) reference electrode, n Bu4NBF6 (0.1M) electrolyte, and ferrocene standard. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images were obtained on a JEM-2100F, JEOL (Japan) microscope operated at 200kV. The samples for HRTEM measurements were taken from the photoreaction mixtures after 10min of light illumination. 2.3 Photocatalytic hydrogen evolution The H2 generation efficiencies of the Ir-PSs were evaluated in a mixture of 0.10–0.50μmol of Ir-PS, 0.30μmol of K2PtCl4, 2.0mL of TEA, 2.0mL of H2O, and 6.0mL of THF, using a 150W Xeon lamp as the light source. Colloidal Pt catalyst was in situ formed from K2PtCl4 in the solution [29]. The amount of the evolved gas was measured with an automatic gas buret, and the gases were analyzed by gas chromatography (GC, Shimadzu, MS-5 A column, TCD, Ar carrier gas). 3 Results and discussions The synthesis of the five new Ir(III) complexes is illustrated in Scheme 1. The cyclometalating C^N ligand 1 was prepared under Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling conditions [34] using 2,4-difluorophenylboronic acid and 2-chloro-4-methylquinoline. A chloro-bridged iridium(III) dimer was then formed by the reaction of IrCl3·3H2O with ligand 1 in a mixture of 2-ethoxyethanol and water [35]. The new Ir-PSs (PS1–PS5) were prepared in moderate to excellent yields by subsequent reactions of the iridium dimer with the corresponding N^N ligand (L1–L5, Fig. 2), followed by ion exchange with KPF6. Fig. 3 shows the FTIR spectra of the new Ir-PSs. A strong peak at ca. 1690cm−1 for the CO stretching vibration of PS3 and a medium sharp peak at ca. 2224cm−1 for the CN stretching vibration of PS4 are observed. The weak broad peaks at ca. 2850–2950cm−1 for PS2 can be assigned to the CH stretching in the vinyl group, while multiple weak peaks at ca. 2850–3000 for PS3 and PS4 represent the CH stretching vibrations in the n-propyl chains. For successful application of the as-synthesized Ir(III) complexes as PSs for photocatalytic hydrogen generation, they have to fulfill various criteria. In addition to the prerequisite light absorption, the formed excited state should survive long enough for effective electron transfer from the electron donor to the Ir-PS∗. Moreover, the reduced Ir-PS species (i.e., Ir-PS−) have to possess sufficient reduction potential to transfer an electron onto the Pt catalyst [35]. Therefore, all the as-synthesized Ir-PSs were characterized by steady-state UV–vis, steady-state, and time-resolved PL analysis, CV/DPV, and Stern–Volmer measurements. Fig. 4 A shows the UV–Vis absorption spectra measured in deoxygenated dichloromethane, with the expansion at 350–600nm shown in Fig. 4B. The strong absorption at ca. <400nm for PS1–PS5 can be attributed to the ligand-centered π→π∗ transitions [36], while the medium absorption at ca. >400nm mainly consists of the MLCT transitions which should be a combination of singlet (1MLCT) and triplet (3MLCT) [37]. Compared to the commonly used phenylpyridine Ir-PS (PS7) [30], the phenylquinoline Ir-PS (PS1) demonstrates much higher absorption intensity at ca. 320–380nm and ca. 380–450nm (Fig. S2, SI†) which can be attributed to the enhanced ligand-centered transitions and MLCT transitions, respectively. This result clearly shows the significance of using cyclometalating ligands to modify the light absorption of the Ir-PSs. However, the effect of the N^N ligand on light absorption is also not trivial. As can be seen from Fig. 4A, the introduction of styrenyl and pyridyl moieties in PS2 and PS5, respectively, leads to nearly 1.5–2 times higher absorption intensity than PS1 at ca. <400nm. The inclusion of formylfluorene and cyanofluorene for PS3 and PS4, respectively, even results in much higher light absorption intensity than PS2 and PS5, and meanwhile redshifts of the absorption threshold from ca. 500nm (PS1, PS2, and PS5) to ca. 570nm (PS3 and PS4). Fig. 5 shows the PL spectra for the new Ir-PSs, and the corresponding emission peaks are listed in Table 1 . As can be seen in Fig. 5, all the Ir-PSs exhibit structured PL spectra, with three peaks/shoulders at ca. 540nm, 570nm, and 620nm, which are similar to their non-fluoro analogue PS6 [30]. This pronounced PL substructure means that high proportion of triplet-state ligand-centered (3LC) characters (i.e., C^N to π→π∗ transition) participates in the excited states in addition to the 3MLCT characters [23,38]. In contrast, the commonly used phenylpyridine Ir-PS (PS7) exhibits broad structureless emission spectrum [30], which is a clear feature of predominant 3MLCT transitions [39,40]. Table 1 summarizes the PL quantum yields (φ PL) and excited-state lifetimes (τ) for the new Ir-PSs. For PS1, φ PL of 0.70 and τ of 2.37μs are similar to those reported for the non-fluoro analogue PS6 [30], but much higher than those (φ PL =0.28 and τ =0.53μs) for the phenylpyridine analogue PS7 [30], due to the much lower non-radiative decay rate constant (k nr =1.25×105 s−1 for PS1 vs 1.36×106 s−1 for PS7 [30]). The φ PL values for PS3–PS5 are basically close to that for PS1, while the φ PL value for PS2 is dramatically lower due to the low radiative decay rate (k r =0.40×105 s−1). The excited-state lifetimes for all the Ir-PSs are among 1.5–2.6μs, giving a strong indication of the triplet nature of the luminescent electronic states of the studied Ir-PSs. Such long excited-state lifetime is necessary for the electron transfer process from Ir-PS∗ to Pt catalyst. CV measurements were performed for the new Ir-PSs in anhydrous dichloromethane, and the obtained spectra are shown in Fig. S3 (SI†). As can be seen, the reduction curves are electrochemically reversible. Therefore, the reduction potentials, E(PS/PS−), were determined from the CV curves with the values listed in Table 2 . However, the oxidation curves are found to be electrochemically irreversible, making it impossible to calculate the oxidation potentials [E(PS+/PS)] from the CV plots. For this reason, DPV (Fig. S4, SI†) was measured to estimate the E(PS+/PS) values, which are summarized in Table 2. Compared to the non-fluoro phenylquinoline Ir-PS (PS6) [E(PS+/PS)=+1.54 V vs NHE], the difluoro analogue (PS1) demonstrates clearly higher E(PS+/PS) (i.e.,+1.85 V vs NHE), due to the electron deficiency of the fluoride. This result indicates that the modification of the cyclometalating C^N ligands can lead to a dramatic change in the HOMOs of the Ir-PSs, which agrees well with the theoretical calculations [29]; that is, the HOMOs are mainly dominated by the C^N ligands and the Ir(III) metal center in the [Ir(C^N)2(N^N)]+ structure. PS2–PS5 have the same C^N ligands with PS1 while bear with modified N^N ligands. These modified Ir-PSs display various E(PS+/PS) values (+1.84–+1.91 V vs NHE), but the variation is very small. It reflects that the contribution of the N^N ligands to the HOMOs is relatively minor. Reduction potential E(PS/PS−) is directly linked to the hydrogen-generation process under reductive-quenching mechanism (Fig. 1). Thermodynamically, E(PS/PS−) has to be more negative than −0.71V vs NHE (the potential for hydrogen generation from TEA/THF/H2O system at pH=12). For PS1, E(PS/PS−) of −1.18 V vs NHE was observed, which remains in the required domain. This value corresponds to a driving force of 0.47eV for the hydrogen generation, which is thermodynamically favorable. For PS2–PS5, E(PS/PS−) values (−0.97 – −1.05 V vs NHE) shift positively due to the lowered LUMOs by the increased π conjugation in the N^N ligands. However, the driving forces for hydrogen generation with PS2–PS5, ca. 0.28–0.34eV, are still sufficient. The excited-state reduction potential, E(PS∗/PS−), determines the efficiency of electron transfer from TEA electron donor to Ir-PS∗. Thermodynamically, E(PS∗/PS−) has to be higher than +0.93 V vs NHE (the potential for TEA – e→TEA+) [42]. The calculated E(PS∗/PS−) values from E(PS/PS−)+E g(opt) are summarized in Table 2. E(PS∗/PS−) for PS1 is +1.22 V vs NHE, corresponding to a driving force of ca.+0.29eV for the reaction, Ir-PS∗ +TEA→Ir-PS− +TEA+. This value is higher than that obtained from the non-fluoro analogue PS6, implying that the fluorination makes the quenching of Ir-PS∗ by TEA thermodynamically more favorable. Interestingly, all the Ir-PSs (PS2–PS5) with modified N^N ligands demonstrate higher E(PS∗/PS−) than PS1, giving higher driving forces of 0.40–0.49eV, which should be beneficial to the quenching of Ir-PS∗ by TEA. Stern–Volmer measurements can provide a straightforward insight into the electron transfer from TEA electron donor to Ir-PS∗ through analyzing the PL quenching of the Ir-PS∗ by TEA [30]. Specifically, the PL quenching efficiencies by TEA follow the steady-state Stern–Volmer equation, PL 0/PL = 1+ K SV [TEA], where PL 0 is the initial solution photoluminescence of the Ir-PS, PL is the solution photoluminescence of the Ir-PS at the TEA concentration [TEA], and K SV is the Stern–Volmer constant. The Stern–Volmer plots are shown in Fig. 6 , and K SV values are calculated from the slopes. Compared with the non-fluoro phenylquinoline Ir-PS (PS6), the difluoro Ir-PS (PS1) demonstrates significantly increased K SV (K SV =4.5 for PS1 vs 0.4 for PS6 [30]). This can certainly facilitate the quenching of Ir-PS∗ by TEA, and that is why fluoro was introduced to the cyclometalating ligands in this study. As can be seen from Fig. 6, the K SV values (ca. 4.9–5.6) for PS2-PS5 are expectedly higher than that for PS1, which can be attributed to the increased E(PS∗/PS−) values. In summary, the UV–Vis absorption of the Ir-PSs can be improved by the modification of both C^N and N^N ligands. The replacement of phenylpyridine C^N ligand by bifluoro-phenylquinoline and the attachment of surface-adsorbing conjugates in the N^N ligands both lead to higher absorption intensity. All these Ir-PSs possess long (microsecond) excited-state lifetimes. The quenching rate of Ir-PS∗ by TEA is improved by an order of magnitude by the fluorination in the C^N ligands, with a further slight increase with the modification of the N^N ligand. Although the values of E(PS/PS−) are slightly decreased with these new ligands, they are still sufficient to drive hydrogen generation. In this study, this new family of Ir-PSs were tested for photocatalytic hydrogen generation. In these experiments, TEA was used as the electron donor, and K2PtCl4 was added as the precursor of Pt colloidal catalyst [29]. It is assumed that the Ir-PS was excited to produce Ir-PS∗ upon light illumination, and then reduced by TEA to form Ir-PS−, which subsequently provides an electron to drive the hydrogen generation on the Pt surface. The evolved hydrogen gas was collected by an automatic gas buret. After each reaction, the gas was analyzed by GC. Besides traces of solvent, only hydrogen was detected. Hydrogen-generation experiments were first performed using a traditional recipe [26] which contained 0.5μmol of Ir-PS in a ca. 10mL of solvent mixture (2.0mL of TEA, 6.0mL of THF, and 2.0mL of H2O). The hydrogen evolution plots as a function of the reaction time for all the Ir-PSs are shown in Fig. 7 . The turnover numbers (TONs) were calculated with respect to single-electron transfer processes, and the results are listed in Table 3 . Turnover frequencies (TOFs) were estimated from the average TONs within the first 5min. For PS1, an average TON of 707 is obtained, which is higher than that (i.e., TON=415) from the non-fluoro analogue PS6. This is mainly due to the much improved TOFs (56min−1 for PS1 vs 20min−1 for PS6), which can be explained from the significantly enhanced K SV, a contribution from the fluorination. However, the hydrogen-generation duration for PS1, < 1h, is basically the same as that for PS6 [30]. This means that the stability of both Ir-PSs is similar and the fluorination does not contribute to the Ir-PS stability. As reported previously [27], the degradation of Ir-PS occurs mainly through the dissociation of the bipyridyl N^N ligand from the Ir metal center in the state of Ir-PS−. The fast quenching of Ir-PS− can efficiently improve the stability. This can be fulfilled by the introduction of surface-adsorbing groups on the N^N ligand, which can enhance the Pt/Ir-PS interaction. As expected in this study, PS2-PS5 with surface-adsorbing groups all exhibit extended hydrogen-generation duration (ca. 2–4h), as shown in Fig. 7. Interestingly, the surface groups also influence the hydrogen-generation TOFs. As can be seen in Table 3, both vinyl and pyridyl Ir-PSs (PS2 and PS5) present slightly lower TOFs than PS1, while both formyl and cyano Ir-PSs (PS3 and PS4) reveal increased TOFs. However, it should be noted that the final TONs (ca. 2500–5500) from all the Ir-PSs with surface-adsorbing groups are much higher than that from PS1. Among them, the formyl Ir-PS (i.e., PS3) demonstrates much higher activities than others. The effect of various surface-adsorbing groups on the hydrogen-generation kinetics can be related to the two factors, the self assembly of the corresponding Ir-PSs on the Pt surface [31,32] and the electron transfer kinetics with different surface-adsorbing groups [27]. However, further understanding on these issues needs more efforts in the future. The Ir-PSs with surface-adsorbing groups are assumed to adsorb on the surface of the Pt nanocrystals, rather than randomly diffusing in the bulk solution [31]. In this regard, the optimal Ir-PS/K2PtCl6 molar ratio in the photoreactions should be different for the Ir-PSs with/without surface-adsorbing groups. Specifically, a relatively lower Ir-PS concentration can be used for those with surface-adsorbing groups [26,27]. For the most efficient Ir-PS, PS3, experiments with Ir-PS amounts lower than 0.50μmol were then investigated. The kinetic traces are shown in Fig. 8 , and TONs are listed in Table 4 . Interestingly, with decreased Ir-PS amounts, the final TONs increase and rise up to over 10,000 at 0.20μmol of PS3. To better understand the effects of PS types and amounts on TON, HRTEM analysis was performed for some representative photoreaction samples involving different types of PSs and/or different PS amounts. Fig. 9 shows HRTEM images for three typical samples, that is, sample A with 0.50μmol of PS1, sample B with 0.50μmol of PS3, and sample C with 0.20μmol of PS3. It was found that the in-situ formation of Pt nanoparticles (NPs) could be influenced to some extent by the types of Ir-PSs and their concentrations. As shown in Fig. 9 and Fig. S6 (SI†), the average Pt particle size is 2.5±0.3, 2.1±0.2, and 1.6±0.2nm for the samples A, B, and C, respectively. In addition, Pt(111) lattice fringes (d=0.23nm) and Pt (200) lattice fringes (d=0.19nm) can be clearly observed from the insert shown in Fig. 9A and B, respectively. It is evident that Pt NPs have been in-situ synthesized, and the size of Pt NPs decreases slightly (from 2.5 to 2.1nm) when PS1 is replaced by PS3 with the same concentration (i.e., 0.50μmol). The Pt NPs size shows a further decrease (from 2.1 to 1.6nm) when the concentration of PS3 decreases (i.e., from 0.5 to 0.2μmol). However, the size change is not big whether PS1 is replaced by PS3 with the same concentration or when the concentration of PS3 is changed from 0.5 to 0.2μmol. Compared with PS1, the smaller Pt NPs size observed for PS3 is probably due to the steric effect of PS3 on the in-situ reduction of PtCl4 2− species. As we know, PS3 with L3 as the N^N ligand, which has two additional surface-adsorbing groups compared with L1 (as evident from Fig. 2), has a longer chain than PS1 with L1 as the N^N ligand, and thus, the Ir-PS3 cations (excluding PF6 − anions in Ir-PS3) have a larger ion radius than the Ir-PS1 cations. Two Ir-PS3 cations with larger ion radius are supposed to surround one PtCl4 2− anion through the opposite charges attraction. Under an irradiation, the Pt(II) species surrounded by bulkier ligand (i.e., L3) are reduced to Pt NPs with smaller size because the bulkier ligand L3 could prevent effectively the fast growth of the in-situ formed Pt seeds and also prevent agglomeration of small Pt NPs into large particles. This phenomenon has been frequently observed and reported in the synthesis of noble metal NPs, for example, using polyvinylpyrrolidone or other surfactants as a capping agent to prevent fast growth of the Pt seeds and stabilize the as-synthesized small Pt NPs [43]. PS3 with the bulkier ligand L3 in our reaction system is supposed to have similar effect as a capping agent. As for the Ir-PS3 with the decreased L3 concentration, Pt NPs show a decreased particle size, which is probably attributed to less Ir-PS species attached on the formed Pt NPs, making the Pt core-Ir-PS shell structure smaller. A further study on the mechanism for the size variation of Pt NPs with PS types and concentrations should be interesting and significant, but it is obviously out of the scope of this work. An investigation into the size effect of the in-situ formed Pt NPs on TON is supposed to be very difficult even impossible because the photocatalytic reaction system in this study is too complicated to change Pt NPs size independently but keep other parameters (variables) unchanged. Furthermore, the size of the in-situ formed Pt NPs is highly dependent on the PS types and their concentrations. Thus, it is difficult to determine exactly the contribution of the Pt NPs size variation to hydrogen-generation TON. To our knowledge, there has not been any report on the impact of the size variation of Pt colloid NPs in the presence of Ir-PSs on photocatalytic hydrogen generation. Although so, we can still make a rough estimation according to the variation of electrochemical active sites of Pt catalysts, which are generally represented by electrochemical active surface area (ECSA). ECSA is an important measure representing the intrinsic electrocatalytic activity of Pt catalysts [1]. Shao et al. [44] recently investigated the effect of Pt NPs size on oxygen reduction reaction. It was reported that ECSA of a Pt-based catalyst increases with the decreased Pt NPs size. Namely, when the Pt NP size decreases from 2.46 to 2.15nm, ECSA increases from ca. 80 to ca. 92m2/g, corresponding to an enhancement of 1.15 times. While the Pt NP size continued to decrease, for example, from 2.15 to 1.5nm, ECSA increased from ca. 92 to ca. 115m2/g, corresponding to 1.25 times of enhancement. Interestingly, the Pt NP sizes and the size variations in their study are very close to that in our study (i.e., 2.5nm observed for the photoreaction sample with 0.50μmol of PS1, 2.1nm for the sample with 0.50μmol of PS3, and 1.6nm for the sample with 0.20μmol of PS3). If we consider ECSA to be an intrinsic electrocatalytic activity of a catalyst, and independent of different electrochemical reaction systems, we can conduct a rough estimation about the contribution of the decreased Pt NP size to the TON of hydrogen generation in our reaction system. When PS1 is replaced by PS3, the TON for hydrogen generation increases from 707 (average value) to 5564 (see Table 3), corresponding to an enhancement of ca. 7.87 times, which is much larger than the enhancement (i.e., 1.15 times observed when the Pt NP size decreases from 2.46nm to 2.15nm) caused by the decrease in the Pt NP size. This may suggest that the influence from the variation of the Pt NP size is much smaller compared with the contribution from PS itself and other factors. Therefore, the huge improvement in the TON of hydrogen generation is supposed to be mainly attributed to the variation of PS types rather than the decreased Pt NP size, namely the introduction of surface-adsorbing formyl bipyridyl groups because the only difference between the reaction system containing Ir-PS1 and that containing Ir-PS3 is that the former uses L1 as the N^N ligand, which does not have surface-adsorbing groups, while the latter uses L3 as the N^N ligand, which contains surface-adsorbing formyl bipyridyl groups. In fact, PSs with formyl bipyridyl ligands have demonstrated much enhanced TON for photocatalytic hydrogen generation due to improved electron transfer from an Ir complex PS to a colloidal Pt catalyst [31]. In the cases where the concentration of PS3 decreases from 0.5 to 0.2μmol, the Pt NP size decreases from ca. 2.1nm to ca. 1.6nm. As reported by Shao et al., when the Pt NP size decreases from ca. 2.15nm to ca. 1.5nm, ECSA shows 1.25 times of enhancement. In our study, when the amount of PS3 decreases from 0.5 to 0.2μmol, the TON for hydrogen generation increases from 5564 (average value) to 10,559 (see Table 4), corresponding to 1.897 times of enhancement. Interestingly, compared with the cases in which different PSs were used (i.e., PS1 was replaced by the same amount of PS3), the contribution of the decreased Pt NP size to TON seems to have increased a lot in the case a large amount of PS3 (0.5μmol) was replaced by a small amount of PS3 (0.2μmol), implying that the decreased Pt NP size plays a more important role in enhancing hydrogen-generation TON if the same type of PS (i.e., PS3) is used. Although so, it seems very hard to say that the decreased Pt NP size plays a more important role than PS itself because the Pt NP size highly depends on the PS types and their amounts. Furthermore, from Table 4, it is also noteworthy that a further decrease in the amount of PS3 (i.e., 0.1μmol) does not enhance TON (i.e., 4022), although the Pt NPs in this reaction system have a smaller particle size (ca. 1.4nm, data not shown) than the reaction system with 0.2μmol of PS3. Lower TON observed for PS3 with an amount of 0.1μmol is probably due to the following reasons. First, without a support Pt NPs with very small particle size are easy to agglomerate to form large particles due to their high surface energy, and PS3 with a less amount (i.e., 0.1μmol) might not prevent efficiently the agglomeration of Pt NPs during the photocatalytic hydrogen generation. Second, PS3 with a less amount (i.e., 0.1μmol) is supposed to have less steric contribution compared with PS3 with a larger amount (i.e., 0.2μmol). Curtin et al. [45] reported that the use of bulkier ligands could minimize solvent access to the iridium center, which presumably stabilized the PS by hindering ligand substitution. This phenomenon was also observed by other researchers who reported a correlation of steric shielding with increased hydrogen evolution [25]. Compared with PS3 with an amount of 0.1μmol, PS3 with a larger amount (i.e., 0.2μmol) is supposed to have bulkier ligands because in the latter case each PS3 has more neighboring PS3, and thus, has bulkier ligands (L3) composed of its own one and the ones from the neighboring ligands. Therefore, a larger TON could be expected for PS3 with a larger amount (i.e., 0.2μmol). The variation of TON with the PS3 amounts suggests that the most contribution to the TON comes from PS itself and the synergetic effects between PS and Pt NPs rather than solely or mainly from the decreased Pt NPs size. In summary, the variations of PS types and their concentrations could change the size of in-situ synthesized Pt NPs. When PS1 was replaced by PS3 with the same amount (i.e., 0.5μmol), Pt NPs size decreased from ca. 2.5 to 2.1nm, probably due to the role of bulkier ligand of PS3 as a capping agent. In addition, it is also found that the concentration of PS3 could influence the size of the in-situ synthesized Pt NPs. When the amount of PS3 decreased, smaller Pt NPs could be formed, probably due to less PS3 surrounding the Pt NPs, which enables the structure of Pt core-PS shell to have smaller size. Although the size of the in-situ synthesized Pt NPs is highly dependent on the PS types and their concentrations, the effect of the variation of Pt NPs size on the hydrogen-generation TON can be roughly estimated if we consider ECSA of a Pt catalyst independent of electrocatalytic systems. In the cases the different PSs are used, the effect from the variation of Pt NPs size is much smaller compared with that from PS itself and the synergetic effects of PSs and Pt NPs. While in the cases different PS3 concentrations are involved, the effect of the Pt size variation on the TON becomes more pronounced. TON increases significantly with the decreased Pt NPs size and decreases dramatically with a further decrease in the Pt NPs size. A maximal TON has been demonstrated by the PS3 with an appropriate amount (i.e., 0.2μmol). Based on the above analysis, the contribution to the enhanced TON from the decreased Pt NP size is smaller compared with that from PS itself and the synergetic effect between PS and Pt NPs whether in the cases different types of PSs were used or different concentrations of PS were employed. PS type is supposed to play a crucial role in the enhanced TON while PS concentration also plays an important role especially in the cases the same type PS is used. 4 Conclusions This study presents the synthesis of a family of Ir(III) complexes with a bifluorinated-phenylquinoline C^N ligand and various N^N ligands attached with surface-adsorbing groups. The bifluorination of the cyclometalating C^N ligand is found to increase the Stern–Volmer constant by an order of magnitude, which reflects a significantly increased quenching rate of Ir-PS∗ by TEA. The attachment of surface-adsorbing groups in the Ir-PSs leads to extended duration for hydrogen generation, which can be related to the fast quenching of the Ir-PS− due to enhanced Pt/Ir-PS interaction. The types of surface-adsorbing groups also influence the hydrogen-generation kinetics, which might result from combinational effects of the self-assembly of the different Ir-PSs on the Pt surface and the electron transfer kinetics with the different surface-adsorbing groups. In addition, it was also found that the size of the in-situ synthesized Pt NPs is highly dependent on the PS types and their concentrations, which also contributes to some extent to hydrogen-generation TON. The formyl Ir-PS (i.e., PS3) shows higher hydrogen-generation TOF than the cyano, vinyl, and pyridyl Ir-PSs. With the formyl Ir-PS, a TON of over 10,000 can be obtained at a relatively low Ir-PS addition amount. This study provides a very good example on how to tune the photocatalytic hydrogen-generation kinetics and stability by manipulating the ligands of metal complex-based photosensitizers. coredata.dc:description: A family of iridium(III) complexes with a general structure, [Ir(C^N)2(N^N)]PF6 (C^N is cyclometalating ligand and N^N is bipyridyl ligand), was synthesized and explored as photosensitizers (PSs) for photocatalytic hydrogen generation using a three-component system containing an electron donor, triethylamine (TEA), a colloidal platinum catalyst and water. The introduction of a novel fluorinated C^N ligand, 2-(2,4-difluorophenyl)-4-methylquinoline, leads to much faster electron transfer from TEA to the excited-state Ir-PSs, as confirmed from Stern–Volmer measurements. In combination with the employment of various N^N ligands attached with surface-adsorbing groups including vinyl, formyl, cyano, and pyridyl, the photocatalytic hydrogen-generation duration is significantly extended. This might be related to the fast quenching of the reduced state (Ir-PS−) resulting from the enhanced interaction between the Ir-PSs and the Pt catalyst. In photocatalytic reactions at relatively low Ir-PS concentrations, turnover numbers of over 10,000 for hydrogen generation can be attained using the formyl Ir-PS.
coredata.dc:title: Molecular engineering of photosensitizers for fast and stable photocatalytic hydrogen generation
